Minden Playing Card Cricket has been around since the early 1980s and is one of the best of the stats-based cricket games. Each turn of the game simulates an over of Test or One Day Cricket. Turns are resolved by using a regular deck of playing cards instead of rolling dice, although six sided dice are used to resolve some plays. The device of replicating a single over per turn is perfect, as full test matches can be played over several hours, while one day games can be played out in a single session. The system ingeniously allows for hat tricks, batting collapses, batsmen playing themselves in, and batsman playing with confidence. There are two forms of the game. Basic, which only include some rules and in which players are not individually carded (although they do have individual stats) and the Advanced Game, in which each player has a unique card.

It produces a very convincing range of scores and excitement (perhaps rather more than the real game does). Extremely clever.

The 5th Edition of this game is now available from mindencricket.com

title: Waterloo
description:
This game, designed by the comics artist Guido Crepax, was published for the first time by the Italian magazine Linus, starting from the issue of December 1965. It was republished in 1999 by the travel magazine Sandokan. Wonderful the stand up paper soldiers designed by Guido Crepax that an uniforms fanatic.

Original description for this game:
An extremely rare, but very playable, wargame on Waterloo. Features beautiful stand up paper soldiers.

title: Rebel Seas
types: American Revolutionary War Expansion for Base-game Nautical Wargame
description:
The British Navy at bay - part one

Rebel Seas is the second volume in Mark Campbell's Close Action series.

Its 20 scenarios cover naval actions in American waters during the American War of Independence. They range from one-on-one frigate actions to grand fleet engagements with over 20 ships of the line on each side. Each scenario contains the same level of research and commentary found in Close Action.

Rebel Seas is the first of three books spanning the years 1774-1792. The other volumes will treat the struggle for India (Monsoon Seas: Suffren's Campaign for India) and England's blockades of its Continental foes (European Seas: The Lifeline of Empires).

(source: Clash fo Arms website)

title: Adventure Park
mechanisms: Pick-up and DeliverRoll / Spin and MoveStorytelling
description: An exciting game that helps children, family, and friends cope with illness.  In Adventure Park, the game board depicts an amusement park, and players roll a die to move their pawn along paths between the various attractions.  Players must collect tickets that enable them to enter the attractions and collect tokens.  Each ticket poses a question that encourages the player to discuss his/her feelings.  Each time a 1 is rolled, the clock (a spinner on the board) is advanced by one hour.  The player with the most tokens after 12 hours is the winner.

title: Marvel Comics Super-Heroes Card Game
types: Card Game Children's Game Comic Book / Strip
description:
This trick taking card game is basically a variant of Old Maid with a Marvel Universe theme tacked on. Deck contains 19 pairs of Heroes (including Spiderman, Captain America and Daredevil) and 1 Dr Doom on oversize cards. Like Old Maid, you draw a card from another player and try to match it to a hero in your hand. Match and discard. First to discard all of their heroes wins; if you're stuck with Dr Doom, you lose.
The best reason to have this game is that the Heroes are drawn by such artists as John Romita Sr, Jack Kirby and John Buscema.

title: Olympiade-spillet
description:
All the players compete in 12 different sports. The winner of the competitions is decided by dice.

Olympiade-Spillet is a children's game about the Olympics. The goal is to compete in track and field games like sprints, hurdles, high jump, long jump, discus and javelin throw. The winner of each competition wins the gold medal (5 points), the runner up the silver medal (3 points) and second runner up the bronze medal (1 point). The one with the most points after playing a number of chosen athletic games is the winner.

Olympiade-Spillet is a dice rolling game with four different types of games.


     Sprints (100 m, 110 hurdles, 400 m, 1500 m) that is a racing type of game
     High jump and pole vault that is about stopping before you roll a to high number
     Long jump and triple jump that is a roll and move type of game
     Athletic throwing games (discus, javelin throw, hammer throw, shot put) that is about rolling the right combination which is given on the board.


Even though Olympiade-Spillet is just about rolling dice it can become an intriguing party game when played with a lot of people, since you can play up to ten people in this game.

title: Game of Flowers
description:
The title of this card game is Game of Flowers (NO. 1126) and was produced in 1899.  Box measures approx. 3 3/4 by 3 inches and contains set of cards, each of which has a flower. Four suits,(A.B.C.D) 13 cards in a suit for a total of 52 per deck. Flowers are geraniums, pansies, lilacs, roses, begonias, carnations,
cornflowers and sweet peas, among others and a set of written instructions for gameplay.

title: Virus
description:
This is a game somewhat like Chess with Stratego-like elements .  The object is to move your pawns into the opponents Virus area or by destroying the opponents two mutants.  
The play pieces are called Mutants, Clones and X's and Viruses.  
A unique twist to this game is that you have the ability to infect the opponents pieces and turn them against their master.

title: Frantic Ants
description: This game features a moving, battery operated track that marches the player's ants uphill and downhill towards the finish line. Each player has 5 plastic ants. On your turn, you spin the spinner and follow its instructions. If you spin a 1, 2 or 3, you place an ant on the first step of the first, second or third anthill respectively. The ant will begin climbing to the top of the hill and slide down the other side (where it starts climbing the next hill). If you spin a Short Cut, move an ant ahead to the Short Cut space. If you spin an Anteater, remove an opponents ant from the track and return it to that player. If you spin ZZZZZZZZ, you're asleep and skip your turn. Since all the ants are moving at once, it's best to make your move quickly. The first player to get all 5 ants to slide down the third hill and enter the Finish area wins.

title: Pastiche
description: Pastiche is a simple sentence-forming game where the object is to create legal sentences from words drawn from a pile. Components include a letter-sized envelope with cover art by Carl Lundgren, 120 word tiles, 40 punctuation tiles, rules, and a set of score sheets. The rules describe three different games that can be played with the same components.

title: Rocket Race
description: Rocket Race is one of the Milton Bradley Flipsiders games that resembles an audio cassette until you flip the game open. The 2 players (starting at either Earth or Mars) compete to race their rockets to Pluto and back. On your turn you move your marker across the board the number showing on either spinner. The A spinner requires you to spend a fuel unit to use (you can refuel by landing on a planet). The B spinner only lets you drift 0 or 1 space. It is used if you are out of, or trying to conserve fuel. You might also spin an Explosion which causes you to lose all your fuel. Go to Pluto and return to your home planet first to win.

title: Das Spiel mit der Schlange
description: Das Spiel mit der Schlange is a limited edition (1,111 copies) expansion for Sternenhimmel, released at Essen in 1995.  The Serpent (Schlange) is always the last constellation played.

title: The Wind in the Willows Game: Rivals, Robbers and Rivers
description:
From the box cover --

Welcome to an exciting new adventure for Badger, Toad, Rat and Mole.  The swollen riverbanks around Toad Hall are buzzing as everyone tries to catch a runaway boat full of stolen booty.  The world that Kenneth Grahame created has been delightfully brought to life within this unique board game.  Based on the illustrations of E.H. Shepard the four playing pieces have been specially commissioned and are made in stone and resin and hand painted.  The backdrop for their adventures is a specially illustrated game board.  This game is a true collectors piece for lovers this timeless classic childrens story

title: Closing the Merida Pocket: Extremadura 1938
description:
Game included with Alea Magazine 18.

The game covers the offensive operations in Extremadura province in July and August of 1938, during the Spanish civil war. Nationalist forces are attempting to crush Republican resistance and end the war.

English rules translations are available.

title: Goose Green: Malvinas, 1982
description:
Game with Alea Magazine issue 17.

Tactical simulation of the battle for Goose Green (Falklands / Malvinas - 1982) between Argentina the United Kingdom.

English rules translations are available.

title: Medellin 1809
description:
Game with Alea Magazine issue 16.

Shadow of the Eagle (La Sombra del Aguila) is a series of games covering the battles of the Napoleonic Wars in Spain (1808-1814). A standard set of game rules is published with an exclusive set of rules for each game.

This game covers the battle of Medellin in 1809.

English rules translations are available.

Game System:
- scale = 250m/hex; 
- time = 20 min/GT; 
- strength = battaillons (inf), regiments (cav), batteries (art).

title: Neues Land
types: Nautical Pirates Renaissance Territory Building Transportation
mechanisms: Action Point Allowance SystemArea MovementDice RollingSecret Unit DeploymentSimultaneous Action Selection
description: Players buy ships and employ traders, priests and conquistadors. They need to transport this people from their home harbor in Europe over the sea to the new world. On the sea they fight against other players, pirates and natural disasters. If they survive and reach the new world, they found trading stations and missions. Trading stations and missions deliver victory points every turn. So you need to burn down trading stations and missions of your enemies to get 25 victory points and win the game before they do it.

title: Gettysburg 1863
description: Gettysburg 1863 consists of 112 pieces , a 29.5 x 42 cm map(printed in English) and 8 pages of rules(in Japanese). Circumference of Gettysburg is printed in a map. Turn length is four hours and units are battalions , brigades or divisions. Player numbers are one or two and playing time is three hours.

title: Tamames 1809
description:
Game included with Alea Magazine 23. First version included with Alea Magazine 2.

Two different games by the same designer. The second is an adaptation of the system La sombra del aguila.
English translations are available.


(from the publisher's website:)

Tamames 1809, scenario for the Shadow of the Eagle series. An optional rule and 60 unmounted markers to simulate Fog of War in that series limited intelligence is included). The game includes 1 DIN A3 map and 86 unmounted counters.

Game System:
- scale = 250m/hex; 
- time = 20 min/GT; 
- strength = battalions (inf), regiments (cav), batteries (art).

title: Operation Ironfist
description:
This wargame is set in 1951 in an alternate world where the U.S. landing at Leyte Gulf was defeated by the Japanese navy. The Japanese still lose the war but it takes longer and the Soviets and the U.S. are forced to invade Japan.

The Soviets have established a communist Northern Japanese people's Republic in Hokkaido while the U.S. establish the democratic state of southern Japan (Honshu and the rest of the Islands).

In 1951, combined U.S. and Japanese forces invade to take back Hokkaido.



This game is also based on Daisuke Sato's novel of the same name.

title: Beakman's World Beakmania Game
types: Action / Dexterity Educational Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
(From the box)
Based on the hit TV show that stars The Umpire of Understanding himself, this game features over 300 Beakmania questions (and answers!) and five great ways to take the Beakman Challenge!

The object (you know, the goal of the game!): be the first player to collect 7 beakers from the lab.  (How? you may ask.) Land on a Beakmania space and answer a question correctly! Meet up with Lester and maybe he'll help you get one! (But do not step on his tail...)

title: Panzer Grenadier: Jungle Fighting
types: Expansion for Base-game Wargame World War II
description:
This supplement for the Panzer Grenadier: The East Front system introduces the U.S. Army's role in fighting the Japanese.

Jungle Fighting includes 42 scenarios from the Guadalcanal campaign. Most of these feature Army troops, but there are also several from the deep penetration carried out by Marine Raider companies behind Japanese lines.

The back of the book is covered by a map of Butaritari Island, also known as Makin Atoll. One of the scenarios covers the August 1942 attack on the island by Marine Raider troops.

Theres also a lengthy background piece on the Guadalcanal fighting, putting all of these scenarios and those from Semper Fi: Guadalcanal in their proper context.

This is an expansion supplement and not a complete game.

This game is part of the Panzer Grenadier series

title: Jungle Hunt
types: Adventure Animals Children's Game Video Game Theme
description:
Ropes are the unique feature to this game. There are five of them which pivot from a spindle perched in the middle of the game board. The game board is divided into quarters. Each of four ropes has its own matching colored section from which it must not leave. The fifth rope may move forward and backward all around the board.

In turn, each player will activate the spinner and move any number of ropes any combination of whatever number was spun. A players explorer (pawn) can only move via rope. An explorer can jump on a rope that is on its space. One of the spaces on the spinner activates the Mad Monkey pawn. Mad Monkey can knock explorers off if they share the same rope.

The first player to lap the game board, therefore reaching Jungle Girl, wins the game.

Based on the famous arcade game from Taito.

title: Firefighter Search & Rescue
mechanisms: Pick-up and DeliverRoll / Spin and Move
description:
From the Rulebook:

There's a fire at the Bakers' house, and the firefighters have arrived to put out the flames and save the family! Are you brave enough to help them?

Rescue family members (including the cat and dog) by carrying them back to START. Avoid flame tiles - they'll slow you down! Earn one Bravery point for each family member you rescue. If you rescue the last family member, you'll earn the Hero Medal, worth 2 Bravery points! After everyone has been rescued, the firefighter with the most Bravery points wins the game!

title: The Game of Capitals
description: This old Parker Brothers game was designed to teach players the capitals of the world. On a turn, you simply draw a card and read the question to the player to your left, such as Of what country is Vienna the capital? If the question is answered correctly, the player keeps the card. Each card has a point value depending on how obscure the country is. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins.

title: Whitetailopoly
description:
A property-trading game. You buy ranches, build cabins and lodges, and charge to hunt.

From the news release By Art Lander Jr.HERALD-LEADER OUTDOORS WRITER:

At the start of the game, players get a bankroll of cash and roll dice to determine the order of play. Players roll the dice to move their pewter pieces around the board, and draw cards that tell them to pay or collect cash. As players move around the board, they pay for taxidermy work, bows and arrows, and firearms, and collect money from winning big-buck contests. If players land on a piece of property they don't own, they must pay to hunt.

title: Hopp Galopp
mechanisms: Dice RollingPress Your LuckRoll / Spin and Move
description:
A bit of luck with the dice will help the children have their horse jump over the hurdles. The referee makes sure that each horse starts from the right spot.

Who will be the first to have their horse jump over the last hurdle?

Game idea:
With the sugar cube, the players determine for themselves over how many hurdles their horse should jump. However, the horse will only be able to make the jump if the colour of the hurdle and the dice don't coincide. If the horse fails a jump it has to return to the referee who makes sure that everybody complies with the rules and is always waiting next to the starting square of the round that is being played.

A coloured die and hurdle race for adventurous players.

Ages 6-99

title: The Flintstones
types: Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme Prehistoric
mechanisms: Pick-up and DeliverRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Dino, the Flintstones' pet, has gotten loose and is wandering about the neighborhood. While roaming, Dino has caused 5 clams' worth of damage to property belonging to Mr. Slate, Fred's boss.

Players roll a die to move through the streets of Bedrock. If you land on a Clam space, you take 1 Clam token for each clam shown. If you land on a Car space, you may move your pawn to any other Car space on the gameboard. If you land on a Red space next to a building, you draw a face down tile from the box. If the tile is an Animal helper, you place it on the building to show that Dino is not there. If the tile shows Dino, you place it in front of you. Another player may capture Dino from you by landing on your pawn by exact count. The first player to return to the Home space with Dino and 5 Clams wins.

title: The Headlines Game
description: In this party game, players make up a four-word headline based on four letters drawn randomly each turn and a randomly drawn category.  Players' entries are judged by that round's editor.  The first player to win five rounds is declared the winner.

title: The Big Idea: More Cards!
types: Card Game Expansion for Base-game Party Game
description:
From the Cheapass website:

The Big Idea: More Cards is a deliciously different assortment of 64 cards for The Big Idea, featuring such gems as Dangerous Cheese, Bulletproof Caveman, and Scandalous Turkey Pants.

You need The Big Idea (semi-deluxe edition) and all the required bits for that game.

Expands:

    The Big Idea

title: Cache-cache à la ferme de Foin-Foin
description:
A children's game Ages 4 and up where one must match animals in order to bring them into their pens.  On your turn you roll, move to a square and turn over a disc from the field without showing it to other players.  If they match you move the disc, face up, to your farm.  You need to get 1 of each animal, 9 total, finishing with Rusty the dog.

English Name: Hide and Seek at the Friendly Farm
Website: www.gladius.ca

title: Ghostly Estates
description: Ghostly Estates is one of the Milton Bradley Flipsiders games that resembles an audio cassette until you flip the game open. Using a spinner for movement, each player moves room by room through the haunted house gathering 4 objects in this order: The Candle, The Map, The Key, The Gold. After both players have taken a turn, the ghost is moved to a random room. If this room is occupied by a player or players, they drop the last object they gathered and must go backwards to gather it again. The first player to return to the START circle on the porch with all 4 objects wins.

title: Coopetition
description: In this party game, players compete and cooperate in a variety of familiar situations - including trivia, drawing, and charades.  Unlike other board games of its kind however, players not only compete to win, but must also work together.  Teams move along the board based on the difficulty of the word or trivia question in the chosen category (Think, Act, Draw, and Talk).  The game involves skill, knowledge, strategy, and luck.  The underlying premise of the game is based on the 1950 PhD thesis of Nobel Prize winning economist John Nash.

title: Prom Date
description: Prom Date is one of the Milton Bradley Flipsiders games that resembles an audio cassette until you flip the game open. The board has 3 tracks: a Guy Path (where you try to get a date with the guy you like), a Date Path (where you find out what happens on your date), and a Heart Path that tracks how much your guy likes you. To start, you select your Favorite Guy. On your turn, you move along the Guy Path (using a spinner) trying to land on a picture of your guy. When you do, you move to the Date Path and travel along it (gaining or losing Hearts depending on how things go). When your marker on the Heart Track reaches the telephone space, you spin the spinner to see if your Favorite Guy will call. If the spinner matches your Favorite Guy space color, he asks you to the Prom and you win.

title: Rock Tour
description: Rock Tour is one of the Milton Bradley Flipsiders games that resembles an audio cassette until you flip the game open. Players take on the roles of rock-and-rollers trying to be the first to finish their tour schedules. A City List track lists all the places where concerts can take place, while the board depicts a map of the world with travel paths to all the concert locations. Using a spinner for movement, you travel on the world map trying to reach one of the next two cities shown on the City Track list. If you do, you advance your City Track marker to that space. The first person to reach New York on the City Track finishes the tour and wins.

title: Marlborough Man
description: This simulates two of the Duke of Marlborough's Battles during the War of the Spanish Succession featuring Blenheim(1703)  Oudenarde(1708) and makes a play on words regarding a more famous cigarette maker. It has two 22-inch by 17-inch mapsheets in four sections that have to be put together, and the game's two countersheets have to be mounted and cut apart prior to commencing gameplay with these. There are plenty of Cavalry involved in these, as well as the Dragoons which seem to be in transition in Historical terms. For the price that you pay, it should be well worth the Value that you'd expect from the acclaimed designer.

title: Are You Phrazy?
description:
From publisher's website:
Chat like crazy, using only well-known and well-worn catch phrases in this frantic, funny game! You might converse like a 60s hippie, 90s hip hopper or 30s hepcat, but always at breakneck and break-tongue speed.

Are You Phrazy Enough To Play?
Its easy. Open the box. Deal out some cards and start gabbing! Begin with a green opener card like WASSUP? Everyone keeps the conversation going by playing  phrase cards like BEEN THERE, DONE THAT!, WHAT YOU TALKIN' 'BOUT, WILLIS?, CAN YOU DIG IT?until someone stops it with a red card like TALK TO THE HAND!

Butting In Is Even Better!
Conversations will get wicked and wild because you can butt in anytime and chat out of turn, just by using identical phrase cards. And since you can win if youre the first person to get rid of your cards, youll be butting in all the time.

Butt! Butt! So will everyone else! That's when the Phrazyness and fun start crankin.

title: Scavengers Gold
description: Scavengers Gold is one of the Milton Bradley Flipsiders games that resembles an audio cassette until you flip the game open. One player controls a scavenger ship trying to loot sunken gold, while the other player controls a naval ship trying to sink the scavenger. Using a spinner, the scavenger player moves across the board trying to land on gold dot spaces (where a different spinner is used to see whether a gold coin is found). The naval player tries to line up next to the scavenger and fire upon it (where the second spinner is used to determine hits). The scavenger player wins by collecting 7 gold coins without getting sunk. The naval player wins by scoring 7 hits on the scavenger ship and sinking it.

title: Tank Battle
description: Not related to the other Milton Bradley game of the same name, Tank Battle is one of the Flipsiders games that resembles an audio cassette until you flip the game open. The object is to destroy the other players tank. On a turn you spin the 2 spinners. Spinner A tells you how far you must move. Spinner B indicates how far you can fire. All firing must be done in a straight line (i.e. you can't shoot diagonally). If spinner B points to a number that is greater than the number of spaces between you and your opponent, you score a hit. Each tank has 7 hit points. Blow up your opponents tank to win the game.

title: Lucky Luke: Wanted
types: American West Comic Book / Strip Deduction
description: Players are Sheriffs trying to capture outlaws and collect reward money. The roll of two dice is split on each turn. One die is for movement, the other corresponds to one of six event cards. Players move from space to space, trying to find the exact hat/kerchief color combination matching the wanted bandit. Notes are kept as players deduce the whereabouts of each outlaw. Event cards can penalize players by eliminating outlaws or restricting a player's movements, or reward them with a free peek at a bandit card. When all bandits have been captured, the player with the most reward money wins.

title: Fantoccini
description:
Fantoccini - The Game of Living Theater

Fantoccini is an adult party game for three to eight couples. In addition to providing mature entertainment, Fantoccini has value in the learning process for college and theater drama groups, and in institutions where the acting-out of conflicts or 'play acting' is a desired form of therapy.

Game consists of: Gameboard with the scene area in the center, the revision wing at the left, and the score sheet on the right; 150 scene cards with green, blue, or yellow backing which color-correspond to columns on the board's scene area; 180 player cards player cards with red backing which color-correspond to the red columns on the board's scene area; 36 square revision cards; two Grand Thespian Certificates; and 16 Fantoccini invitation tickets, each admitting a couple to your party. These properties will allow for two complete Fantoccini parties.

The object of Fantoccini is to become Grand Thespian...the first player who has filled all 12 squares on the scoresheet by acting 6 times, having Authored twice, having been Wardrobe Lady twice, and having been Critic-Censor twice.

Players write their names on the blank side of 6 red cards. The revision cards are dealt equally to all players. Each color-coded deck is shuffled separately and placed face down. Place scene and player cards face down on the first free row of the scene area in the proper colors (green, red, blue, red, blue, red, blue, yellow).

Reveal the scene by turning over the cards on the row, announcing the scene as it unfolds. The green card establishes where the scene is played. The red and blue cards define the actor and their role (duplicate red cards are replaced with another red card so that there are 3 different actors). The green card establishes the players' motivation. For example, In a bomb shelter, Bob (a prim spinster of 30), Marge (a raspy throated dice player) and Hank (a politician) are saving a life. The three actors go into another room and prepare the scene (should run 2 - 3 minutes).

Players bid for Author (may reassign roles or replace a scene card), Wardrobe Lady (provides costume items) and Censor-Critic (an arbiter of whether or not the scene will be played and judge of the scene's quality based on audience response and the critic's opinion).

The scene is played (or not, based on the Critic), evaluated and participation tallied. Lay out a new scene face down on the next free row and continue with new scenes until a player tallies all 12 squares on the wipe-off score area and is declared the Grand Thespian.

title: Fluppy Dogs
types: Children's Game Memory Movies / TV / Radio theme
description: This is a simple childrens memory/matching game based on the Disney cartoon characters. The board is a slotted raised platform that sits in the box. The 24 Fluppy Dog cards each depict 2 dogs (an upper and a lower) of various colors. These cards are inserted into the board slots to hide the lower dogs. On your first turn you draw a card and keep it to start your chain. From then on when you draw a card, if the color of the lower (hidden) dog matches a color at either end of your chain, you connect it (ala dominoes). If the color does not match, you place it back in a board slot. Thus you need to remember where hidden Fluppy Dogs are put back so you can find the ones you need to make a color-match. The first player to collect 5 cards in his or her chain is the winner.

title: Flying The Beam
description:
This old game, designed by Captain William J. Chapman, an army pilot, is based on actual blind flying conditions. When flying the beam, the pilot hears a steady radio buzz when he is on his true course. If he flies to one side of the beam, he hears the Morse code letter A (.-); if to the other, the letter N (-.). As he nears the On Course signal, the letters A and N will superimpose on the On Course buzz in what's called the Twilight zones. Finally, as the pilot approaches the radio sending station adjacent to the airport, the signal fades out into what's called the Cone of Silence.

The object of the game is to land safely at the airport. Each player places his marker on the Leg of the beam nearest them. The start space tells you which lane (A, N, or center) your plane begins its approach on. On your turn, you spin the spinner and move your plane the number of spaces indicated towards the Cone of Silence in the center of the board. You must follow the directions for any space you land on (usually these cause you to shift lanes). When the Cone of Silence is reached, you spin for a runway number to land on. The first player to land by exact count on their assigned runway space wins.

title: Follow That Mouse
types: Children's Game Memory Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
This is a childrens memory game with a Mickey Mouse theme. In the basic game, each player takes a board with 6 shapes of various colors on it. On a turn, you draw a tile from the centerboard and look at it. If it matches the color and shape of a space on your gameboard, you place it on the empty board space. To win, be the first player to fill your 6 spaces with matching tokens.

In the advanced game, players use the reverse sides of their boards. Each board depicts a different land at Disney World. Play is the same for the basic game, but you must match the pictures on the tokens to the corresponding Disney ride depicted on your 6 board spaces.

title: Military Chess
description:
An abstract military-themed game. Uses a modified 64-square chess board divided by a river crossable at four bridges. Each side also has two minefields on its side of the battlefield. Each army has 12 hard plastic pieces depicting various soldiers or weapons. There is a General (chess King), two Cannon (moves like a chess king but can fire at enemy pieces up to three squares away instead of moving), one Tank (chess Rook), one Bazooka-man (can move up to 3 squares in any direction), one Jeep (same as the Bazooka-man), two Infantry (can move up to two squares in any direction) and four Advanced Guard (can move up to two squares in any direction EXCEPT backwards.)

The object of the game is to eliminate the opposing general or move your own general to the other end of the board.

The game was originally marketed by A.N. Meyers  Co. (London) as a New Game for the Chessboard in the 1880's.

title: Danmarks mester
description:
This is a combination of a trivia and a scrabble game.
You move around on a map of Denmark answering questions. By answering correctly you win a letter. Whoever can make the highest scoring word at the end of the game wins.

title: Blag!
description:
The game is a pictorial bluffing game, consisting of photographic picture cards, counters, board, pencils and answer pads.

Similar to Balderdash, players have to create captions for photographs which one player then reads out. Scores are awarded for each guess of your false answer, for guessing the correct answer etc.

title: Hammerslag
description: Based on a Danish TV-program. The object of the game is to try to estimate how much a house/apartment cost around Denmark. In your estimate you have to consider the location location location...

title: Den store P3 Quiz
description: Trivia game based on a popular public radio. Questions in seven different categories.

title: Taxa
description: A taxi game with a map of Copenhagen. Pick up customers (red, blue, green, silver, and gold), deliver them to their destinations and get the next. Whoever delivers at least one customer in every colours win.

title: Group Photo: Scooby-doo!
types: Card Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description: From the tin:  Scooby-Doo, where are you?  It's time to round up Scooby-Doo and the rest of the gane in a fun new family card game full of intrigue and surprise.  Zoinks!  Hilarious character bios, wild cards and 21 of the most popular Soooby-Doo characters make every game unique and FUN!  Like wow!

title: Supporters
description:
A magazine game from Jeux  Stratgie Nouvelle Formule #8.

Two groups of sports fans try to get as near as possible to the soccer field to support their teams.

title: Forbidden Fruit
description:
This old card game plays similar to Go Fish. There are 10 different kinds of fruit (30 cards - 3 of each type) with a guard for each. The guard with the 3 cards it protects forms a set. The cards are distributed equally amongst the players. On a turn, you may ask any player for a fruit provided that you yourself hold either a fruit or the guard from that set. If the player has the fruit asked for, he must give it up, unless he has the guard of that fruit; for example, if one player asks another for an apple which he has, if he also holds the dog, he may refuse, saying, My apples are guarded by my dog.

You continue calling for fruit until you call on a person who either doesn't have any or has the guard for that set. Once stopped, all players draw 2 cards from the player to their left. Guards cannot be called away, but since they are frequently passed, their location is often doubtful. When you collect all 4 cards in a set, you lay them down in front of you. The player with the most sets at the end is the winner.

title: Fox and Hounds
description: In this track game one player becomes the Fox and the others act as the Hounds. The Fox has the first move, spins the spinner, and advances along any path the number of spaces indicated. The Hounds then spin in turn, trying to capture the Fox by landing exactly on the space the Fox occupies. The Fox is safe on the Red track, but must move out on his next turn. If the Fox can reach the Fox's Den space by exact count, before being captured by one of the Hounds, he wins - otherwise the player whose Hound captures the Fox wins.

title: 101 Dalmatians Puppy Rescue Card Game
types: Card Game Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme Novel-based
description: The object of this childrens game is to construct the longest line of rescued puppies. This is accomplished by bidding for either a Puppy card or a Cruella De Vil card as it is turned up from a draw pile. With a hand of numbered bidding cards the players bid simultaneously as each card is turned. High bid rescues a puppy and low bid must take a Cruella De Vil card. Once all the cards are won, and after subtracting one puppy card for each Cruella De Vil card held, the player with the longest line of rescued puppies wins.

title: HotFlash! The Menopause Game
description:
The object is to make your way around the board and be the first to reach Hormone Free Haven. Along the way, win or  lose, youll have plenty of opportunities to laugh and learn.

When you land on Raging Hormones youll discover some little known facts about women, your body, peri-menopause, and lots of other stuff.

When you land on a HotFlash!, youll have a chance to act a little goofy or ask your friends about some deep, dark secret like Have you ever had a one-night stand?

Be sure to avoid PMS Purgatory, and be careful not to go down the Fallopian Tubes. Theyll take you backwards through Weepy Way, Lustless Lane, Bitchy Boulevard, Insomnia Aisle and The Forgetful Forest.

Whether you play to win or just play to play, after an evening of HotFlash!, youll never think of Menopause the same way again.

title: Pet Hunt
description:
Each player starts with a hand of cards.  On each card are four pictures of pet shop animals (goldfish, puppy, turtle, etc.).  A set of smaller cards is turned over one at a time.  On these smaller cards are two animals, sometimes one or both will have a red X over it.  To win, players try to get rid of all their cards by matching them to the requirements on the small cards.  So, if a small card shows turtle not-kitten, any card a player has with a turtle but no kitten on it can be discarded.

The game is attractive and the play is quick.  It has a minor educational value, teaching pattern recognition and very, very light analysis.  Winning is entirely a random prospect.

The game will play well with very young players.  Optimally, I think Ages3 - 5
 is the right age for it, though the game box says Ages 4 and up
.

The game includes 35 big cards, 28 small cards, a tray, and rules. The storage box is conveniently small (no over packaging).

Awards include:
Great American Toy Test - Recommended - 2002
Oppenheim Toy Portfolio Gold Award - 2002
Oppenheim Toy Portfolio Best Educational Toys - 2002
Canadian Toy Testing Council Three Star Award- 2003

title: Duckula Card Game
description: Duckula Card Game is a licensed merchandise of a 1980s-90s British cartoon series about a vegetarian vampire duck.  Players are given a hand of five cards in the game.  During their turn, they must take a card from the deck or discard pile and then discard one from their hand.  The first player to reveal a hand that has a Castle Duckula card and a unique set of character cards (of the same character and numbered from 1 to 4) wins the game.

title: Augen auf!
description:
Augen auf!, turns the entire room into the game board. 50 task cards show what is to be searched for in the room. Ten game stones with the numbers from zero to eight and +-sign are placed in a circle on the table. The top card is revealed by the starting player and all players are looking at the pictured object and counting how many of them are in the room. If a player believes he or she knows the number, he or she grabs the stone with the correct number and calls stop. If there are as many objects in room as number in the stone player gets the task card. The player who gets most cards wins.

Ages 5 and up.

title: Meine kleine Farm
description:
Here is a description of the game from Spielbox:

Meine kleine Farm is by Ralf Menzel. It consists of stalls, dice and tiles on which cute little baby animals are depicted. The animals, afraid of a thunderstorm, have hidden themselves in various stalls. With a good memory and a little dice luck, the players set out to search for the animals - whoever finds an animal gets points.

title: Hokkaido Republic
description: This is an alternate reality Japanese wargame by Ad Technos and is set in a world where Japan resisted Admiral Perry and the U.S. was forced to invade Japan(to open it up to the rest of the world). General Custer also makes an appearance as he did not die in Little Big Horn.

title: Astrology: The Game of Prediction
description: This game teaches basic concepts of Astrology. It was designed by two Astrologers to be an easier way to learn the basics of Astrology and the meaning of planetary/star sign relationships. They seem to have done a good job at that, unfortunately, game play seems to be little more than roll the die, move pawn, draw card. A nicely designed board, very unusual movement die (Very large 12 sided with one of the 12 signs of the zodiac on each side, as well as a loose ball inside) and a cool, 70's look to the game. An interesting product from an interesting decade.

title: NBA-opoly
description:
From the publisher, Late for the Sky:

Heres a property trading game with an interesting spin NBA-OPOLY! Collect and trade your favorite teams with all the speed and excitement found in the NBA. Its family fun that fans will want throughout the season and into the playoffs. NBA-OPOLY makes a great gift for Ages 8 and up
(2-6 players).

title: Maelstrom Expansion Pack
description:
From the publisher, Fantasy Flight Games:

The Masters of the Void are at war. Tearing through the fabric of the universe, they are summoning their minions and strongholds from across the planes to do battle and help them dominate the center of existence itself: the Vortex. For the one who controls the Vortex controls the universe.

In Maelstrom, you play a Master of the Void, fighting your opponents for control of the Vortex. Build your army of minions and strongholds, summon them to the battle, and unleash them against your opponents forces. The Expansion Pack gives you more minions and strongholds to control and help you gain control of the universe.

The Maelstrom Expansion Pack is designed to supplement and expand Maelstrom. The Maelstrom Expansion Pack contains 15 assorted flats containing 45 tiles not available in the Maelstrom set. Maelstrom is playable in 30-90 minutes.

Expands:

    Maelstrom

title: Dino-opoly
description:
From the publisher, Late for the Sky:

DINO-OPOLY is a game based on those fascinating creatures of times gone by - Dinosaurs. It has all the fun of a traditional property trading game with some prehistoric twists. The game board features everyones favorite dinosaurs from giant-sized herbivores to teeny tiny carnivores. Players trade their Fossils in for a Dino Bone to be the big winner in DINO-OPOLY! Each DINO Deed features fun facts about that particular dinosaur. Game play is forAges 6 and up

title: To the Sound of the Minuet: Mollwitz 1741
description: Simulation of the battle of Mollwitz, 1741 during the war of Austrian succession. Battalion-regiment level.

title: Find Ambi
description: This is a humorous game base on catching a leader of a Danish sect. Move around by rolling a dice and try to capture the criminal

title: Tegn og gæt exclusive
description: A team game where you pick a card which states your assignment which is to be drawn so that your partner can guess what your assignment is.

title: Kogepunkt
description:
Kogepunkt is a trivia game focused on the theme of food, in which up to 4 teams of players can attempt to become the winner.

Each team takes a token and places on the starting point on the board.  On their turn, they roll a die and move their token by its result.  They then have to draw a card and answer a question (asked by another team) about the category they landed on.  Categories include utensils, drinks, ingredients, background of certain foods, and miscellanous questions.  Correct answers (and moving their token a complete circle around the game track) awards the team a Chef Hat.

The game ends when a team manages to obtain a pre-agreed number of Hats, thus making them the winners.

title: Kongespillet
description:
Trivia game with questions on the the Danish kings and queens.

Awards

2002 Årets Voksenspil, Adult Game of the Year Denmark

title: Game of Extraordinary Gentlemen
description: A simple race game that involves rolling a die and moving the corresponding number of spaces along a fixed track. Most spaces either require the player to roll a certain number to resume movement or move the player to some other space. Included in The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen Volume 2 comic book collection, it is probably better as a joke than as a game.

title: Zur Kasse bitte!
description:
Here is a description of the game from Spielbox:

Zur Kasse Bitte! by Jurgen Heel deals with an everyday situation: We're going shopping at the supermarket, but nobody has written down what he needs. Was that eggs, milk, tissues...? More and more of the 60 ware cards come onto the table. At some point, a player grabs the stack and calls out To the checkout, please!. At that point, whoever best remembers the wares wins.

title: Sakhalin 1945
description:
This game concerns one of the last battles of World War 2. The invasion of the Southern Sakhalin and the Kuriles by the Soviet Union. This was done in conjunction with the invasion of Japanese held Manchuria and Korea in the wake of the atom bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The Soviets surprisingly had a hard time in taking the Sakhalins and the Kuriles even though they outnumbered the defenders and had overwhelming advantage in firepower, the Japanese defenders fought fanatically and there were still pockets of Japanese resistance at the time of the armistice.

Sakhalin 1945 consists of 86 pieces, a 29.5 x 42 cm map (printed in English) and 10 pages of rules (in Japanese). The map covers from the Japanese/Soviet border at the 50th Parallel through the strategic town of Koton. Turn length is twelve hours and units are a platoon, companies or battalions. Player numbers are one or two and playing time is two hours.

Came out in Six angles #3 and as part of the Six angles collection

title: Rommel's Afrika Korps
description:
This is a Ginichiro Suzuki's game on Operation Crusader.

100 counters.

title: Deutschland unter Geld
description:
This is a strategic treatment of WW2 in Europe like The Third Reich in microgames format.
Units are moved after resource spending.

title: Iraq War 2003
description:
This is a Japanese wargame simulation on the current U.S. led invasion of Iraq in 2003.

200 counters.

title: Fleet Battles 1933-1945
description:
BRAND NEW from Sunset Games Japan, the new revised edition of the old Hobby Japan classic, Fleet Battles 1933-45. Fight all the great naval encounters, historical and hypothetical, from 1933 - 1945. this game has 800 beautiful counters of all the ships from the navies of : Germany, Italy, Japan, USA, British, Polish, Dutch, Romanian, Soviet, Norwegian, Turkish, and more!! New Rules/charts in Japanese, but old English rules/charts from Tsukuda Hobby's version of Fleet Battles included, new version of English rules/charts not available yet, but in the works! not too hard to figure out how to play! This is VERY RARE outside japan, very hard  expensive to import!

Fleet Battles is a game that does IJN in remake(IJN is Imperial Japanese Navy.)
As for this game, a part of content is different though the name is the same as the HJ version including the rule.

title: The Wall Street Game
mechanisms: Commodity SpeculationRoll / Spin and MoveStock Holding
description:
The object of this stock market game is to be the first player to accumulate $1,000,000.00 in cash.  Players make money by buying stocks low and selling them high, and by dividends which are paid to stockholders.

The market goes up when a stock is bought and goes down when a stock is sold.  Players also get to influence the stock market when leaving the inside track and when landing on certain squares. Stocks vary in price at different rates, so the game provides a unique slide rule-like Market Level Calculator which players use to figure out how much a stock is worth at any given time.

title: Frenzied Finance
description:
This is an old card game with a stock market theme. A blue-backed deck of stock certificates is shuffled and placed in the center of the table. The top card (called the Boom card) is removed from the top of the deck and hidden under the box. A second deck identical to the first (except that it is red-backed) is then dealt evenly amongst the players who spread them face-up in front of themselves on the table. Each player also receives 10 chips to use as money.

The dealer draws the top 4 cards from the blue deck and they are paired up their duplicates from the player's red cards and removed from the game. Then a trading round commences in which players may buy or sell their red cards at whatever price in chips they can agree to. After 3 minutes, the trading round ends and another 4 blue cards are drawn, paired, and removed from the game, followed by another round of trading and so on.

When only 1 red card is left, it is paired with the Boom card and a scoring round begins. The player in possession of the Boom card scores 25 points. In addition, all players score 1 point for each chip they have in excess of their starting 10. The cards are then dealt again for a new hand. The game is won by the first player scoring 75 points.

title: Friends At Work
description: This is a childrens memory/matching game with a Sesame Street theme. Each player takes one of the 4 game boards - a Post Office, Fire station, Police Station, or Construction Site. Each board has 4 spaces depicting items you'd find at that location. The 18 picture disks are then shuffled and placed face down in the center of the table. On your turn, you draw a disk and try to match it by color and object to one of your gameboard pictures. If it does match, place it on your board. If it doesn't match, return it to the center area. If you draw a Dump Truck disk, you must return one of the disks on your board to the center area. The first player to match all 4 gameboard pictures with disks wins the game.

title: Fronts & Backs Memory
description: This is a standard childrens memory game with the added twist of trying to match the fronts and backs of objects. A player turns over 2 cards, and if they depict the front and back of the same object, places them in front of him or her. If they do not match, the player's turn ends. When all the cards have been matched, the player with the most pairs wins.

title: All My Ducks
description: The happy little ducks slide down the dock and into the water over and over again. Splish, splash, oh what fun! But which ducks are yours? The colors on their tummies show you which are yours. So pay close attention and remember where your fuzzy friends are. Now, everyone into the pond!

title: Frosty The Snowman
types: Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme Racing
description:
The object of this game is to bring Frosty back to life by being the first player to reach his Magic Hat. Before you can do this, you'll have to complete the rest of his costume by collecting 6 Costume Cards: mittens, boots, scarf, broomstick, corncob pipe and eyes of coal.

Using a spinner for movement, you first travel along the outer track. If you land on a space with a Costume Card that you don't have, you keep it. When you have all 6 Costume Cards, you may move to the inner track. The first player on the inner track to land on the Frosty Space finds Frosty's Hat and wins the game.

title: Furby Adventure Game
description: This is a simple childrens game based on the Furby toys. The object is to be the first player to get their Furby home to the Furbyland cloud. On your turn, you draw a card and advance to the space on the path that matches the color on the card. If you draw a Black Cloud card, you follow its instructions. If you land on a Blue Cardboard Cloud, you pick it up, do what it says, then remove it from the game. The winner is the first player to reach the Furbyland cloud.

title: Tour de Force
description:
A Trivia Game with a Canadian flavour and a twist. There are over 50 categories and 5000 Questions on varied topics such as television, sex symbols, rock and roll, books and authors, religion, hockey, comics, fads and foibles, politics, the occult, wicked women and many more.

A board has a 9 randomly placed categories. You choose the category and it is replaced from the stack. Questions have varying point values and answering correctly will move you forward that number of points.

The credited designers are well known Canadian writers. It is unclear there role in the game design.

title: Digganob
types: Expansion for Base-game Fighting Humor Miniatures Science Fiction
description:
Digganob is the expansion to the humorous Gorkamorka game.

It adds three types of mob to the basic games and contains new scenarios with which to exercise them.

The box contains a 96-page soft-bound rule-book and cardboard models for 4 mutie tents and a crashed spaceship along with a number of counters.

title: Necromunda: Outlanders
types: Expansion for Base-game Fighting Miniatures Science Fiction Wargame
mechanisms: Campaign / Battle Card DrivenDice RollingModular BoardRole PlayingVariable Player Powers
description:
Outlanders is the Necromunda supplement.

The box contains a 112 page soft-bound rule-book, 2 card buildings, 12 plastic bulkheads (used to build 3D terrain), various counters and 5 card barricades.

The supplement expands the Necromunda game by introducing four new gangs (Ratskin Renegades, Redemptionists, Scavvies and Spyrers).

Also included are new scenarios and a bestiary of under-hive nasties.

Expands:

    Necromunda

title: Race Around Britain!
description:
Race to a place...and show what you know! it says on the box. Move around the British Isles and answer questions to collect cards and tokens and get home first. The questions were set by Michael McKissick Hughes and Eamon Bloomfield.

Starting at a random town, players race to twelve other towns aiming to be the first one there.  The first person there gets two points and can answer a trivia question about the destination for another point.  Then it's on to the next town and finally back to the start for three extra points.  Winner is the player with the most points.

Movement is by rolling 1d6 and if you land on an opponent you can move him five spaces in any direction - usually backwards.

This is similar to Journey Through Europe, but the map is of the UK, with UK-specific questions.

title: Ork and Squat Warlords
types: Expansion for Base-game Miniatures Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Ork and Squat Warlords is an expansion for the Space Marine game.  It contains a 76 page rule-book which has 10 color pages in the center.

The rules include details of the Ork and Squat (space dwarfs) forces including their titans.

The Orks have a plethora of troop and vehicle types with typically Orky names like braincrusha, speedsta and giblet grinda.  Their titans are called gargants.

The Squats are much more sober with elements such as the Goliath mega-cannon, land train, colossus and leviathan.

Expands:

    Space Marine

title: Get Hooked
description:
A light card  board game that simulates a fun day on the water fishing for that trophy fish.  Players can take one of three actions on their turn (move their boat, change their lure, or catch a fish).  If you have the right lure and are at the right part of the lake, you are able to play fish cards to win.  Other cards allow you to thwart your opponents' actions with cards like Broken Line.

A fun concept that is easy to grab on to.  Perfect for the person who enjoys fishing and may or may not enjoy a good game as well.

title: Game of Football
description: This game, simulating the American gridiron version of football, comes with a game board representing a football field, a football pin, two pins with colored heads to be used as a 10 yard marker, a dice cup and two dice. As in real football the object is to advance the ball over the opponents goal line for a score. Dice rolls are used for all aspects of the game. The kickoff, for example, travels a distance equal to 5 times the throw of the dice. The receiving player then rolls the dice for the return; if it's an even number, the ball is brought back the number of yards rolled, but if it's an odd number no gain is made. The offense may choose either a Line Plunge, an End Run, a Forward Pass, or a Trick Play. The greater a play's potential for gain, the greater risk of no gain or a loss of yards. A roll of doubles results in either a penalty or a turnover. When the time limit agreed upon by the players (before the game) is reached, the player who has the highest total score is the winner.

title: The Jiggin' Game
description:
Get your boat, get your bait and get your flotation device... then you're off to fishing on the Grand Banks of Newfoundland.

If you forget your fishing permit then you're back onshore and just try and find the boat launch area.

This is a fishing game where the object is to gather the required items to make your boat ready to launch and then make your way to the fishing grounds and pull your quota from the oceans.

title: Grouping The Flags
description: This is an old Parker Brothers card game of set collection. The deck consists of six groups of Flags of eight colors each (Black, White, Green, Red, Yellow, and Blue) and four Key cards. The object of the game is to collect a complete set of eight Flag cards AND a Key card. The entire deck is dealt out to the players. On your turn you may ask any player for a specific card, Please give me Number Four Black. If the player has the card asked for, he must give it to you and you may continue your turn by asking for another card. Your turn ends when you demand a card from a player who does not hold it. A Key card may be asked for at any time. The first player to obtain a complete group of nine cards wins.

title: Sugar Plums
description: In this childrens game, players travel across Sugar Plum Country trying to be the first to reach the Sugar Plum Tree. On your turn, you spin the Sugar Plum Fairies' magic spinner and advance along the Sugar Plum Trail to the color you spun. When you pass over, or land on, a place marked Take A Sugar Plum, you draw a (wooden) gumdrop from the bag. Once you have four gumdrops, you may head for the Sugar Plum Tree in the center of the board. You must be careful of your gumdrops - because, if another player lands on your space, you must give that player one of your gumdrops. The first player to reach the Sugar Plum Tree with four gumdrops is the winner.

title: My Guy Game
description:
From the designer:

Playing involves drawing cards from piles and moving pieces around a board while collecting male characteristics, lines and Hottie! photos. Players can trade cards with one another to construct the best guy possible. Girlfriends help decide whether players get to keep their guys, and then players can draw Future Together cards to see what lies in store for them. At the conclusion, a group rendition of the song My Guy or another favorite tune is strongly recommended.

title: Gargoyles Audio Cassette Game
types: Action / Dexterity Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
This game, based on the animated TV show, is actually two games-in-one. Side A of the audio cassette is used for the game on one side of the board, and Side B is used for the game on the other.

Game #1 is a track game in which players try to find the Grimorum Arcanorum, an ancient magic spell book that is hidden somewhere in New York City. The audio tape narrates the story and tells the players how far to move and whether it's day or night. Players flip a Transformation Disk to see if they are allowed to move that turn (depending on if they're turned to stone). The first player to reach the spell book at the end of the track is the winner.

Game #2 is a dexterity game in which the villains have stolen computer disks that would let them create Gargoyle robots. The villain targets are set up on the locations indicated on the board. Each player takes a Gargoyle Glider. Whenever the narrator identifies a target (Xanatos, Demona or The Pack) you aim at that villain and toss your glider at it. The player whose glider lands closest to the designated target takes one computer disk token. The first player to collect three computer disks wins.

title: Gargoyles Stone Warriors Battle Card Game
Typecast
description: Typecast is a guessing game about the assumptions our society makes based on personal appearance. Each card contains a photo of a person who has been polled with regard to their likes and dislikes. Based on the photo, the players must guess which choices are true about the subject, such as whether they are a a tax lawyer, musician, zoologist, cab driver or photographer. The first player to answer two out of three correctly wins the card, and the first to collect five cards wins.

title: Eye-Dentify
description: Eye-Dentify is a simple game of the observation genre where famous artwork by the likes of Picasso, Miro or Van Gogh are examined by all for a period of 10 seconds. Players note as many details as possible in one minute, and win points for the most details noticed that no one else did. Thirty points will win the game.

title: So you think you know about Ireland
description:
This is a trivia game concentrating on Ireland: History, geography, politics, rumor, movies, folk tales, etc. The game consists of 104 cards (two of which detail the short rules). The cards have questions on one side of increasing difficulty, answering each of which correctly scores points (more points for harder questions). The difficulty progression is different on each card, so one card may have three easy, one medium and one hard question; while another may have two, two and one.

If a player cannot answer a question, the card has four multiple choice possibilities on the reverse for each question. Taking this option halves the points for a correct answer. Correctly answering allows you to keep being asked questions and scoring from the same card. A wrong answer has the card discarded and play passes to the next person.

The game has no given end conditions; either a fixed number of rounds or a time limit seem reasonable. Most points at the end wins.

title: Valgkamp
description: This is a political game in which you and your party tries to win an election using every means possible.

title: Fyrtøjet
description: This game is built on Hans Christian Andersen's children tale the tinder box. Each player is the soldier from the story and tries to win the princess and half of the kingdom by answering questions and roleplaying.

title: The Lifestyle Game: Knowledge Deluxe
description: A trivia game based on life style, fashion, design, art, wine, food, international trade, travel and luxury questions

title: Danmark trivia game
description: In Danmark trivia game you have 400 cards with 2400 questions from six categories : Miscellaneous, History, Sport, Culture, Nature and Geography. All questions concern Danmark only. Collect a token from each category to win. The players roll a die to move and then they must answer a question from the category they land on. If they answer correctly they get a token and when they've gathered tokens in every colour, they can head to the capital (center). First they need to get to a corner of the board where they answer a question of their own choosing. Then there are two coloured spaces from the corner to the center. When the players get to the center they answer a question of the other player(s) choosing. A correct answer in the center means victory!

title: Danmarks Mester Junior
description: Trivia game for kids with questions on Denmark

title: Life is Ruff
description:
From the instructions:

Concept:

Life is a cycle of paychecks, bills and taxes that make it seem almost impossible to 'get ahead.'  It has even been said that there are only two certainties in life...death and taxes.  Today, of course, there is a third certainty...INFLATION!!

LIFE IS RUFF is about the cycle of income vs. outgo.  As in reality, the proper investments can help you beat inflation and ride the waves of a fluctuating economy.  In somewhat simplified terms, LIFE IS RUFF offers the player the same investment opportunities he has in real life and gives each player the opportunity to make investment decisions.  But any opportunity not taken may be lost, for inflation hits when you least expect it.

There are those who will gamble, who will feel lucky, who will try to beat the odds and make a killing.  For those we have included the stock exchange and futures market.  There is a fortune to be made there, or lost.  A player may choose to speculate in real estate, buy a home to get a tax break or keep his assets liquid by renting.  All of these choices, and more, are yours and after all LIFE IS RUFF is only a game...or is it?

OBJECTIVE:

Each player attempts to obtain a survival package of items that have intrinsic value and are counter-cyclical to inflation.  (Their value rises with inflation instead of declining.)  Players, of course, must have cash to purchase these items (gold, silver, food storage, collectibles, diamonds, property) and the purchasing power of the dollar declines as the game progresses causing prices to rise.  The player who has the greatest number of survival assets (points) when RUNAWAY INFLATION strikes (making paper money worthless) is the best prepared and is the WINNER.

title: George of the Jungle
description:
George of the Jungle fearless ape man! A protector of the weak and innocent, lurching through the tree tops he somehow outwits his opponents as he saves his friends...

This is a simple track game based on the animated TV show. The object is to reach George's Jungle House. On your turn you roll a die and advance around the board the number of spaces indicated. You may collect Elephant cards (that add or subtract from your die roll) by taking branch paths to tiger spaces. If you land on a Hazard space, you are stuck there until released by George. On your next turn, you roll the die and advance a George pawn down the George Track the number rolled. When he reaches your space you are freed. The first player to reach the finish space by exact count (Elephant cards help here) wins the game.

title: Goats on Boats
description: Goats on Boats is a childrens memory matching tile game. The player that matches the most goats on boats pictured tiles wins. Game came be played solo, it also has several goat and boat facts on the back of each piece.

title: Goodbye Mr. Chips
description: This is a simple track game based on the novel. The object is to move through the boarding school to get to the assembly hall and graduation. On your turn, you roll the die and advance the number of squares indicated. When you reach the Mr. Chips space, you spin the Mr. Chips spinner sending you to a random board location. If you land on a Pompeii space you take an extra turn. The first player to get to the assembly hall, graduates and wins the game.

title: Keeper of the Estate
description:
This game is part of a series (#4 of a series)-- see Keeper of the Castle for #1 of the series. The rules on the box are rather difficult to understand, though they are brief. Figuring out what these rules mean would require attempting to play the game without understanding it at all. From the box, but really incomprehensible (grammar and spelling mistakes in the original!):

2. - Player may take any item to start with but not jump or land on any item from then on.

3. - When an item lands on 'C' square player draws a card:
  A. If own item place face up in front of player.
  B. If an opponents item, give them the card which they place face up in front of them.
  C. If card from position not being played place face down in discard pile.
  D. If a Missed Payment card take item back to start.
  E. If a Paid off Mortgage card take item to finish position. Home!
  F. If you draw an opponents Open House card give them the card and you get 3 rolls of the die. (3 extra turns).

4. - The only time an item is safe is when the player has the card face up in front of them.

5. - The exact number must be rolled to get into the Bank as well as Home and if all items reach finish position before player has all their cards, they draw a card on their turn until they have all five cards. If a Missed Payment card or  Paid off Mortgage card is draw, disregard and place in discard pile. If you draw an opponents card rule 3B applies and if an opponent draws your card Rule 4 applies and the item starts over.

6. - If all the cards are used up and there is no winner reshuffle the cards, place back in the Estate and continue following the above rules until there is a winner.

title: Safari Tours
description:
Memory game with a twist...
Who can remember where its animals are hiding? Flip three cards and see if you can find them!

Game components: 
15 double-sided animal tiles
30 expedition cards (4 degrees of difficulty)
instruction sheet

title: Sokrates
description: Trivia game with questions based on philosophy.

title: Death in the Trenches: The Great War, 1914-1918
Intrigue
description:
(From the inside box cover)

Intrigue is a fascinating game involving foreign agents, secret information and murder. The action takes place aboard an ocean liner tied up at an American seaport. A diplomat courier has been murdered, and his briefcase, containing secret papers, has been stolen and hidden in one of the staterooms.'

'The object of the game is to be the FIRST DETECTIVE to locate the stolen briefcase and take possession of it.  Clues are obtained by searching the staterooms and meeting opponents in the passageways of the ship.'

title: Takeaway
description:
Unlike many of the other Jax, Ltd. games, Takeaway doesn't seem to have previously existed as public domain.

Luck seems to play a heavy part in this game, advertised as strategic: This is a set collection game, where you collect cards by making plays of cards between your cards and your opponents. At least, that seems to be how the game works: the instructions are well known to be less than specific.

The game seems to be well regarded by younger players, perhaps because they are not as concerned with playing by the official rules.

Verbiage from Jax, Ltd:
Take all you can get...when you play this unique, new family card game! Collect as many cards as you can by making plays between your cards and your opponent's cards. But BEWARE....Your opponents might take them all away! The player with the most cards at the end of the game wins!! It's challenging and fun. When you change comes, take all you can get and play Takeaway!

title: Bible Bingo
description: This is simply bingo with a Christian theme. The caller randomly draws a cardboard chit and the players match its background color, pictures, and/or a Bible verse reference with like squares on their cards.  Blank squares are provided to cover matches.

title: Sound Alikes A game using homonyms
description:
The object of the game is to score the most points. Roll the dice to determine the order of play. The highest roll gives the clues first. There are 2 groups of words: one group has 2 homonyms and one group has three homonyms. The group of 2 is worth 10 points and the group of 3 is worth 20 points. Keep score on the points provided.

The player going first chooses a card with 2 homonyms and reads the clue to the player with the second highest roll of the dice. That player has 10 seconds to say the homonym. If he/she cannot, the next player in order has a chance etc. When that card is done the player with the second highest roll reads the clues to the other players. After all have read a clue with 2 words, a card with 3 is read.

The game ends when time expires (agreed upon) or when all the cards are read. The player with the most points wins.

title: Fight Dice
mechanisms: Action Point Allowance SystemArea MovementDice Rolling
description:
Fight Dice is a freely downloadable PDF-based dice based combat system adapted for action figure battles.  Players allocate (six-sided) dice from a pool for each action figure to allow for movement and/or combat.  Combat consists of sets of dice rolled for attack and defense (as allocated,) defense dice that are equal or higher cancel attack dice, the number of remaining attack dice are removed from the defender's dice pool.  Movement is one inch for each die allocated to movement.  Advanced rules allow for enhanced movement/range mechanics, foreign objects, grappling, etc.

The game guidelines state that a standard human gets 8 dice, a martial artist 20 and a Gundam Fighter gets 36.  Players are encouraged to use their imagination to assign values to action figures.

title: Kharkov 1943: le coup de maître de Von Manstein
description:
This game is a two in one as it contains all the material for TWO battles of World War 2: Kharkov (1943) and Rostov (1941) both happening in the same corner of USSR.

A fourth game of a planned series of six which all use the same rules, on 6 page leaflets.  Published in a issue of Casus Belli and then used for a wargame tournament, the last two of the series never saw the light of day.  Each game containing the global rules and a sheet of paper with the specifications for the scenario.  Three of those 6 games were published by EuroGames: Moskva, Kharkov(Rostov) and Kursk. 
Strategical scale: Battalion, Division, Army Group.

A turn is 4 days long, an hex represents around 10kms.
The battle centers around tanks, but Infantry and Cavalry are an important element. Planes and Artillery are simulated with points which affect the game.

Weather affects combat and movement as both battles (Kharkov and Rostov) happen in autumn/winter. Russian forces are better prepared for the weather conditions, while German forces are better equipped.

Victory is gained by destroying opposing troops and conquering towns to score Victory Points.

title: Main Street
description:
This game has a series of 5 different games for players of varying ages.

From the rules:

Like its predecessor, GOOD OLD HOUSES, this game focuses player attention on specific architectural details and on the stylistic variety of historic buildings.  MAIN STREET, however, brings attention to downtown buildings, structures which, in the hustle and bustle of commercial life, escape the notice of even frequent passers-by.  Our illustrations show each style with its original storefront, but because storefronts are periodically remodeled, one is lucky to find historic storefronts intact.  MAIN STREET players will find themselves looking at the upper levels of commercial buildings to recognize styles they have learned in the game.

The range of styles in MAIN STREET from Federal to Art Deco/Modern, isn't intended to encompass the breadth of American Architectural history, but to represent some basic styles often used in commercial buildings between the late eighteenth and mid-twentieth centuries.

The eight building puzzles (nine pieces per puzzle) are used in five different games for 1 to 8 players Ages 5 and up.

title: Space Hulk Campaigns
types: Expansion for Base-game Fighting Miniatures Science Fiction
mechanisms: Action Point Allowance SystemDice RollingModular Board
description:
Space Hulk Campaigns is a book containing additional missions and rules that greatly expand and enhance the popular Space Hulk game system.  This is not a complete game. Copies of  Space Hulk and both the Space Hulk: Deathwing Expansion and Space Hulk: Genestealer Expansion expansions are required to play all of the campaigns within the book.

This 85 page hard backed book includes 24 new scenarios which can be played stand-alone or as four complete campaigns.  A campaign is a linked series of between four and six missions where the outcome of each mission affects the overall chance of success in the campaign.

The included campaigns are:

The Last Stand
Four linked missions where four Space Marine squads attempt to defend an Imperial outpost from Purestrain and Hybrid infestation.  Can they hold out until the relief garrison arrives?

Genestealer Invasion
Six linked missions.  The Terminators and Librarians of Septimus V  attempt to destroy a Genestealer patriarch deep inside the body of a crashed Space Hulk.

Necromunda
A clever set of six linked missions split into two waves.  The Marine player gets to choose squads of Marines and Librarians from army lists and must first contain the Purestrain and Hybrids, then discover and exploit their weakness for total victory.

Sentinel V
Four linked missions split across two levels where six squads of Terminators attempt to locate and destroy a Patriarch guarded by Purestrain and Hybrid Genestealers
 The book also includes a host of new rules including Space Marines in power armor (ie normal non-Terminator Games Workshop Space Marines,) rules for crack, frag, plasma, blind and melta grenades and rules for Traitor Terminators.

Games Workshop figures for  Space Marines in power armor and Traitor Terminators are required to play the expanded rules for these units.

Expands:

    Space Hulk
    Space Hulk: Deathwing Expansion
    Space Hulk: Genestealer Expansion

title: Metropolis
description:
Long flat box, only two pages of rules. Drive cars around a city (roll a die to move) and purchase building lots of various values (green - highest, yellow - middle, red - lowest) and types (plaza, industrial, apartment, municipal, business). Hard board map depicts building lots, and various movement effect spaces (stopping arrows in different directions and configurations) - you collect money and can change direction of movement). When you purchase the lot you take the card for that lot.

You subsequently build on those lots based on certain restrictions (eg. 3 undeveloped residential lots can be built over if you buy a plaza lot). Subsequent activities include auctioning, mortgaging, trespass fines.

Pretty basic looking as a game. Out of print.

Contains 48 plastic buildings.

title: Data Boxing
description:
Data Boxing features yesterdays legends and hall of famers reflecting the glory days of years gone by. You'll find Ali, Marciano, Dempsey, Louis, Tunney, Foreman, Frazier, Baer, Braddock and more.To quote the designer of the game, Dr. Julian Compton, from a Data Boxing Newsletter (in 1977), One of the real thrills for this game player is to see the stars of the past come alive in a game structure. Usually these names will be familiar, but ever so often an unknown will rear his head in a bid for greatness.

Data Boxing is the boxer's Boxing Game. It's a detailed, realistic simulation of boxing where boxers of all eras are matched.  There is a real component to it because it's based on the actual performance of boxers. Individual fighters are rated on cards, and bouts are resolved through dice and charts and/or rounds cards (see Data Boxing II below).

Data Boxing is based on decades of study and research. It began as a research project in 1967 by humanities professor and boxing authority, Dr. Julian Compton (1940-2010). The heavyweights were evaluated on up to 155 variables. The table game first appeared in 1976. The computerized version was first released in 2004 which is set up similarly to the board game. The computer implementation was done by NASA programmer Don Mankowski.  Data Boxing was featured in the December 1977 edition of Ring Magazine, The People's Almanac [1978], Computer Sports Match-ups [1981] and in the December 13th, 2006 issue of the Tallahassee Democrat.

title: Program IV Baseball
description: Small game designed to simulate professional baseball, consisting of just eight pages of rules and charts.  No teams were included with the game, but rather instructions to rate teams based on real-life statistics.  Games were then played with dice and the charts provided.

title: Program IV Football
description: Small game designed to simulate professional football that consisted of just eight pages of rules and charts.
